596:
Hello, it's nice to meet you. The medication you were taking, thyronorm, is usually used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition where your thyroid isn't producing enough hormones. When this happens, the TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone) from your pituitary gland is high as it's trying to get your thyroid to produce more hormone. Your initial TSH level of 7.8 is slightly elevated, which indicates mild hypothyroidism. It's great that your levels have come back to normal, but you should not stop taking this medication without consulting your doctor. Even if your TSH level is normal now, it could increase if you stop the medication. 

As for your blood pressure, it's important to keep it under control. If left untreated, high blood pressure can lead to severe complications including heart disease, stroke, and kidney disease. Even if it's in the starting stages, it's important to manage it properly. This usually includes regular medication, but also maintaining a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, and reducing stress.

To summarize, my suggestion would be to get back in contact with your doctor and let them know what you've done. They can give you advice based on your full medical history. Remember, you should never start or stop taking medication without consulting a healthcare provider. Stay safe.
597:
Hello, I understand your concerns about your mother's health.

Her Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) of 21 and increasing creatinine levels show that her kidney function is diminishing. This, along with her symptoms of high blood pressure and muscle cramps, are signs of Chronic Kidney Disease.

At this stage, managing her conditions that can cause further kidney damage, like high blood pressure, is crucial. Prescribed medication for blood pressure must be taken as directed. It's also important to manage her diet – low in protein, salt, and potassium can help control the accumulation of waste products in her body.

Regarding dialysis, the decision to start primarily depends on her symptoms, not just her lab results. If she has symptoms like severe nausea, vomiting, difficulty breathing, or if she is not able to take medications or eat, then dialysis may be necessary.

However, it's crucial to have this discussion with her Nephrologist who will be able to evaluate her condition comprehensively and provide the best options. 

To lower her creatinine levels, it's important to ensure she's staying well-hydrated, avoiding strenuous exercises, and limiting intake of high protein foods such as red meat. 

Any changes in her treatment plan or diet should be conducted under the guidance of her healthcare provider. It's also necessary to have regular monitoring to evaluate her kidney function and make adjustments to her treatment as necessary. 

Best regards.
598: Hello, I understand your concern. Pus cells in the blood and urine indicate an infection in the body, most likely a urinary tract infection. The presence of occasional fever suggests that the infection might still be present or her body is still fighting off the remnants of the infection. It's good to know she has already received treatment and is feeling better. However, the complete recovery time depends largely on her overall health condition, how severe the infection was, and how well her immune system is functioning. Please make sure she completes the full course of prescribed antibiotics, even if she feels better before they're done, to make sure all the bacteria are killed. Encourage her to stay hydrated as this can help flush out the bacteria. If her symptoms don't resolve or get worse, you should consult with her doctor. It might be necessary to conduct further tests. Make sure her diet is nutritious and balanced to boost her immune system. Please don't hesitate to ask if you have any more questions.
599:
Hello and thank you for reaching out. Primosa and Evion 400 are dietary supplements which contain Evening Primrose Oil and Vitamin E respectively. They could potentially decrease breast pain and promote general breast health, likely the reason your doctor has prescribed these medicines. However, they do not specifically dissolve fibroadenomas.

Fibroadenomas are benign (noncancerous) and usually do not increase the risk of breast cancer. While some fibroadenomas may shrink or disappear over time, others may remain the same or even increase in size and can sometimes cause discomfort.

Treatment choices for fibroadenomas usually depend on symptoms, size, and other factors. Some options include watchful waiting, medication or various types of surgery. It's crucial to have regular follow-ups with your doctor to monitor the fibroadenoma.

I would recommend discussing your concerns with your prescribing doctor. They would provide the best advice as they are most familiar with your health situation.
600:
I'm really sorry to hear about your situation. It sounds like you've had quite a traumatic injury. The things you're experiencing--the loss of smell and taste and the strange smell you're noticing--are likely related to the brain injury you sustained. These senses are controlled by the part of the brain that was injured. This can sometimes improve over time, but the improvement can be slow and may not be complete. The memory loss for events around the time of the injury is also common with this type of injury,
For the best possible recovery, it's important to have regular follow-ups with your neurologist. Since you're asking about options for treatment, you may also want to find a rehabilitation specialist who can advise on strategies for coping with these changes, perhaps a neurologist or ENT specialist. Please make sure to discuss these symptoms with your doctor, if you haven't already. They may have additional recommendations or refer you to a specialist who can help. As always, regular check-ins with your primary care provider can help make sure you're recovering as well as possible.
601:
Hello, it seems you are dealing with a common skin condition called ichthyosis Vulgaris, which presents as dry, flaky or scaly skin. It's usually more common or severe in areas like the lower legs, torso and especially thighs. 

There is no permanent cure for Ichthyosis vulgaris, and treatment mainly aims to manage the symptoms. It's important to keep your skin moisturized. You can use over-the-counter products such as petroleum jelly, thick creams such as Eucerin or Cetaphil, or creams or lotions containing lactic acid or urea, which help to remove excess scale. Apply these immediately after a shower to lock in moisture.

Cerave SA Cream for rough and bumpy skin is often recommended and can be used along with physical exfoliators like exfoliating brushes or mitts to help remove dry skin patches.

If these methods have not been successful, you should consider visiting a dermatologist who may prescribe a higher-strength lotion. 

Remember, your skin may look clear when you use the cream, and become flaky when you stop because the skin condition is long-term, and consistent use of the cream will be necessary. Regular mild exfoliation will also be beneficial. 

Make sure to avoid harsh soaps or body washes that can strip your skin of its natural oils. Use gentle, hypoallergenic soaps or body washes.

Also note that exposure to the sun may make your condition worse,
602:
Hello. I understand your concern. Acute pancreatitis can be quite painful and distressing, sorry you had to go through this. Long-term effects of acute pancreatitis if any, can be chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic insufficiency or diabetes, but these are not common especially if you had only one episode and it was managed correctly. Majority of people recover completely from acute pancreatitis and go back to normal life without long term complications.

About your heart rate, an increased resting heart rate could be due to several factors like stress, anxiety, dehydration, or a side effect of some medication. Regular cardiovascular exercise actually helps to lower the resting heart rate but keep in mind certain medications or caffeine can increase the heart rate. If you find consistently elevated heart rate, it's best to consult with your primary care physician or a cardiologist to rule out any cardiovascular issues. A simple EKG and blood work can help in providing further insights. Keep on maintaining a healthy lifestyle as this helps in overall wellbeing.
603: Hello, those symptoms could be caused by both a virus or food poisoning, as both can cause gastrointestinal symptoms as well as weakness, aches, and pains. Food poisoning often, but not always, occurs soon after consuming the contaminated food and might include more severe gastrointestinal symptoms like severe cramps and vomiting. Viral illnesses often come with additional symptoms such as fever, cough, or runny nose, and the aches can be very severe. If your symptoms persist, or if you have additional symptoms such as high fever, bloody stool, severe abdominal pain or signs of dehydration such as decreased urine output, dizziness or dry mouth, please seek medical attention.
604: Hello and thank you for reaching out. Tinnitus, or ringing in the ears, can be a challenging condition to manage as the underlying cause can vary greatly from person to person. The treatment and prognosis would therefore depend on this cause. Some people find relief with methods such as noise suppression therapies or certain medications, but there unfortunately isn't a universal cure. It's important to continue working closely with your healthcare provider to manage your symptoms and explore potential treatments. As for the cost, it can vary widely depending on the services provided and the specific healthcare provider. Tests can include hearing exams, measurement of the pitch of the tinnitus, and imaging tests such as MRI or CT scans. I hope this information is helpful and I encourage you to keep communicating with your doctor about your concerns.
605:
Hello, I'm sorry to hear about your symptoms. It certainly could be an allergic reaction, considering the timing of your symptoms along with the recent changes in your environment (new paint and carpet). These materials can sometimes emit volatile organic compounds, which could trigger allergies in some people. Your symptoms of itchy eyes, throat, and skin are all common symptoms of an allergic reaction.

I would recommend taking some steps to alleviate your symptoms, such as using an air purifier to help clear out any potential allergens in your home. Over-the-counter antihistamines might also be helpful.

If these symptoms persist or worsen, then it would be a good idea to get evaluated by a healthcare provider. They may be able to provide more targeted treatments and could also do allergy testing if needed. Please let me know if you have any other concerns.
606:
Hello. Fatty liver disease is often associated with obesity, high cholesterol and triglycerides, and insulin resistance (related to Type 2 Diabetes). Depending on the cause of your fatty liver, your doctor may recommend losing weight if you're currently overweight or obese, reducing your cholesterol and triglyceride levels (Via diet or medication), controlling your diabetes (if applicable), and yes, avoiding alcohol, which can stress the liver. 

In terms of diet, you should follow a balanced diet that's high in fruits, vegetables, protein, and whole grains. Aim to eat lean protein such as fish or chicken, and minimize intake of red meat. Avoid added sugars and saturated fats. Regular exercise will also help. Fatty liver can progress to more serious liver disease, so it's important to manage properly. Always consult your healthcare provider before taking any new medication or supplement.
607:
It sounds like you may be suffering from wrist tendonitis or another form of repetitive strain. This condition can occur without a specific injury and is often related to repetitive movements or overuse. Other symptoms can include pain, difficulty moving the wrist, reduced strength, and sometimes swelling or warmth.

However, other conditions such as early arthritis or a ganglion cyst could also cause similar symptoms. It's important to get a proper diagnosis, as the treatment can vary depending on the underlying cause. I'd recommend you to arrange an appointment with your GP or a physiotherapist who can fully assess your wrist. They may suggest an x-ray or MRI for further investigation if needed.

In the meantime, try to rest your wrist as much possible and try to avoid any movements that cause pain. Over-the-counter anti-inflammatory drugs and simple painkillers can help reduce pain and swelling. A wrist support brace can also provide some temporary relief.

Most importantly, don't ignore this issue as it has been persistent for a few months. Left untreated, it can lead to chronic problems and potentially affect the function of your wrist. 

Please keep me updated with your condition. You know your body best, if the pain continues or worsens, seek medical attention promptly.
608: Hi. Thanks for reaching out. It seems like the stringy substance that you are feeling could be part of the gauze or dissolvable stitches that are placed post-surgery, especially if you had a surgical extraction. However, bleeding 5 days post-extraction is not a typical occurrence. While it can be normal in smaller amounts, a steady stream of bleeding needs attention. Try biting down on a clean, damp cloth or gauze. If the bleeding doesn't stop, I would recommend you contact your dentist or oral surgeon right away. In the meantime, avoid any activity that could exacerbate the bleeding such as spitting, rinsing, smoking, or drinking from a straw.
609: Hello Kaye. Considering that you are asthmatic, and currently suffering from severe bronchitis with notable wheezing, it would be advisable to seek prompt medical attention. It's important to manage these asthma exacerbations early to avoid any possible complications. Even if your infection is viral, you may still require additional therapies like inhaled bronchodilators or possibly a short course of oral corticosteroids to manage your asthma symptoms. Additionally, if there is any concern that you may have a secondary bacterial infection, a course of antibiotics may be necessary. Please make sure to seek emergency care if you have shortness of breath.
610:
Hi Jawed. Your symptoms suggest that you may have gastritis or a peptic ulcer - these can definitely cause upper abdominal pain. It is common to have such symptoms due to acidity or gastritis. As you mentioned, you're already taking medication (Happi-D),  which is a combination of Rabeprazole and Domperidone; it's a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that reduces acid production in the stomach.

As far as your diet is concerned, milk can sometimes worsen the symptoms of acidity in some people. It varies from person to person. Instead of milk, try having a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and grains. Avoid spicy, fatty, and fried foods. Also, try to eat smaller, more frequent meals instead of three large ones.

If your symptoms persist, it's important to have a complete evaluation by a gastroenterologist to rule out other conditions, like gallbladder issues or pancreatitis. 

Remember that this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may not apply to your situation. Always consult with a healthcare provider for appropriate examinations, treatment, testing, and care recommendations.
611:
Hi, it seems like you may be experiencing a condition called erectile dysfunction. Erectile dysfunction is often caused by stress, anxiety, or other mental health factors. However, physical conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, hormonal imbalances, or nerve damage could also be the cause.

The 'water' you mentioned is likely pre-ejaculate, a normal fluid that the body produces when sexually aroused. This does not typically interfere with erection or sexual activity.

For an effective treatment plan, it would be best to consult with a healthcare professional who can help identify any underlying issues, whether they are physical or psychological. They may suggest lifestyle modifications, psychological counselling, or medications, depending on the root cause of the problem.

In the meantime, try to reduce stress through relaxation methods such as meditation or yoga, maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet. Avoid alcohol, smoking and illicit drugs, all of which can impact sexual performance. Please consult with your healthcare provider for personalised advice.
612:
Hello Sue, thank you for reaching out. The heartburn feeling you're experiencing is likely because of the gastritis caused by the H.Pylori infection itself. Even though you have started taking the treatment, it might take a few days to start seeing improvement. Don't worry, this is common. 

In addition to the Eso Kit, your doctor might be able to prescribe a medication to help control the stomach acid and reduce the heartburn. An over-the-counter antacid might also be useful. However, it's important you communicate this symptom to your referring physician. If pain persists, an evaluation should be done to assess for ulcers which might be causing the heartburn. You should also try avoiding spicy foods, alcohol, caffeine and anything else that seems to worsen heartburn. 

Remember, for the Eso Kit to be effective, it's important that you finish the complete course of therapy, even if you start to feel better. If symptoms persist or worsen, please seek further medical attention. 

Remember that these are only my suggestions based on the information provided, and should not replace the advice of your doctor. Set up a return visit with your doctor to discuss these concerns.
613:
Hello, I am sorry to hear that you are not feeling well. Your symptoms can be caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). When the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) does not close properly and stomach contents leak back, or reflux, into the esophagus, this can cause heartburn and other symptoms. However, repeated vomiting can be due to many different conditions, so it's important to investigate further if this continues. It can be caused by gastric outlet obstruction, certain medicines, and gallbladder disease, among other causes.

In terms of what you're currently doing, continue taking your prescribed medication. Additionally, try to make lifestyle interventions .e.g., Avoid foods and drinks that trigger your heartburn (everyone’s triggers are different, but often include coffee, chocolate, foods with a lot of fat or oil, and alcoholic drinks), eat smaller meals more frequently throughout the day, avoid lying down too soon after eating – try to stay upright for at least 2 hours
If you're still not finding relief after these changes, please let me know and we can explore other treatment options.
614:
I'm sorry to hear about your sister's ongoing health issues. It sounds like she's having a lot of discomfort. The hand tightening you're describing could be a condition called hepatic myopathy, or could also be due to an electrolyte imbalance. 

The "lumpy and mushy" feeling in her right calf is likely due to edema or excess fluid retention, possibly caused by her liver disease and ascites. With severe edema, pressure can leave a dent in the skin - this is known as "pitting edema". 

Both of these symptoms suggest that her body is having difficulty managing fluids, and could be indicative of her liver disease progressing. It's important to share these new symptoms with her healthcare provider, who can adjust her treatment plan accordingly. 

They might make changes to her medication regimen to help relieve these symptoms. Diuretic medications, for instance, can help reduce excess fluid in the body and could possibly help with her leg cramps and edema. The doctor might also suggest changes to her diet, such as reducing sodium intake, to help manage fluid levels.
615:
Based on your symptoms and the exposure to smoke from the BBQ, it sounds like you may have irritated your respiratory tract. This could cause inflammation, making it difficult to breathe. This type of symptom is usually transient and should resolve on its own within a week or so. If it doesn't, or gets worse, see your doctor.

In the meantime, drink plenty of fluids, avoid smoke and other irritants, and consider using a humidifier. Rest allows your body to repair itself. Non-prescription remedies such as steam inhalations can also help alleviate these symptoms. However, if the symptoms continue or become severe, such as experiencing severe difficulty breathing, chest pain, or if you start to cough up mucus, it is important that you seek medical attention immediately. I hope this helps, and I wish you a quick recovery.
616:
I'm sorry to hear about your husband's continued discomfort following his treatment for laryngeal cancer. 

The lingering symptoms (mucus production, swelling, pain) that he is experiencing are common after-effects of radiation therapy. Irradiation can result in inflammation and changes in the mucous membranes inside the mouth and throat, leading to increased production of mucus, discomfort, and potential difficulty in swallowing.

It is important to maintain open communication with your husband's doctors about his symptoms, as they may recommend remedies to help provide relief. Over-the-counter medications, prescription medications, or various throat lozenges could potentially be recommended to help manage excess mucus. 

Additionally, drinking plenty of fluids can help thin the mucus, making it easier to cough up. The use of a humidifier might also help break up mucus by keeping the throat moisturized.  

The recovery period varies for everyone, and unfortunately it might take longer for some people, especially considering his age, as it can affect the healing and recovery process. 

Please remember that although these symptoms can be distressing, they are expected to improve over time. Patience and continued communication with his healthcare team are key during this recovery period.
617:
Hello. I'm sorry to hear about your son's condition. Allergic bronchitis is a condition often linked to asthma, characterized by cough, wheezing, shortness of breath. It's true that it can be caused by an allergic response to environmental substances. However, in your son's case, if this is the first instance of such a severe reaction, it is wise to consider other potential causes as well.

This could be a severe respiratory infection, which may cause high fever, congestion, and difficulty breathing. The preceding period of a dry cough may well have been an early symptom of this infection.

 It would be crucial to monitor his symptoms closely. If there's no improvement, or the condition worsens, I strongly suggest he be evaluated by a pediatric pulmonologist or a similar specialist.

Remember, internet advice can never replace personalized medical advice, so ensure to always talk to your pediatrician regarding your son's health issues.
618: Hello. Although you've had two periods since the last time you had unprotected sex, the changes in your periods and your symptoms could suggest pregnancy, though they could also be attributed to other conditions or hormonal variations. Given your history of recent surgery and the fact that you are actively trying to conceive, I would recommend taking another pregnancy test, ideally with a first morning urine sample, as the hormone HCG, which is present during pregnancy, is usually highest at that time. Given the negativity of previous tests, the chance of pregnancy may be less, but it's still worth testing again. If the result is negative and your symptoms continue, I would recommend seeing your healthcare provider to discuss these symptoms. Lastly, remember that with only one ovary, it may take longer to conceive, but it's still very possible. Be patient and take good care of your health in the meantime. Good luck!
619: Hi, it seems like you could possibly be experiencing muscle spasms or have a trapped nerve, usually, these symptoms can happen after chiropractic manipulation if the muscles around the spine become irritated. I would advise you try resting your back, applying ice for the first few days to alleviate any inflammation, after which you can switch to heat to help soothe your muscles. Over-the-counter pain medications can be used for short term relief. If it continues I would recommend seeing your healthcare provider for a proper evaluation, or returning to your chiropractor and explaining these new symptoms to them.
620: The persistent cough and metallic taste could potentially be side effects from the antibiotics or steroids. However, if your symptoms are persisting despite finishing most of the prescribed medication, it would be advisable to revisit your doctor. They will be able to determine if further treatment is necessary or if your symptoms are simply a side effect of the medication that will clear up with time. It's always best to consult a healthcare professional if you're unsure or concerned about your symptoms. Please do not stop taking prescribed antibiotics unless advised by your healthcare provider.
621: I'm sorry to hear you're feeling this way, but I'm unable to assist with your situation. It's really important to talk things over with someone who can, though, such as a mental health professional or a trusted person in your life.
622: Hello, I'm sorry to hear that you're not feeling well. The symptoms you're describing could potentially be due to several conditions, including gastritis, an ulcer, gallbladder disease, or even a kidney issue given the lower back pain. These conditions can cause abdominal pain, especially following meals, and may be associated with other symptoms like chills and headaches. 623:
Hello. It sounds like your friend is experiencing significant stress and perhaps some anxiety or paranoid thoughts, especially the part about colors and seeing people are trying to communicate with her through them. This might be a symptom of a possible mental health issue. Further evaluation is needed to rule out various conditions such as mood disorders, anxiety disorders, or even more severe conditions such as schizophrenia.

For now, the best thing you can do as a friend is to encourage her to see a mental health professional. This could be a psychiatrist or psychologist. They can properly diagnose her and suggest appropriate treatment. Please ensure she doesn't feel alone during this time. Assurance and understanding from loved ones makes a lot of difference. Remember to take care of your own emotional health too, as it can also be a tough time for you. I highly suggest you propose the idea to her or, if she's comfortable with it, accompany her to a visit to the healthcare professional. Till then, try maintaining a calm environment around her. Do not reinforce or challenge her beleifs, instead divert the conversation to a neutral topic. 

I hope you find the advice helpful. Please write back if you have any other concerns or need clarification on these points.
624:
Hello, persistent fever during pregnancy warrants investigation. Fever is the body's response to an underlying condition, and while it's generally not harmful to the baby itself, the condition causing the fever, whether an infection or other illness, might be. This is why it's important to identify and treat the underlying cause. Additionally, long-term (chronic) fever in rare cases may lead to preterm birth or low birth weight, so it's important to seek medical attention promptly. 

Given your fever for 4 days, I recommend you to visit your doctor as soon as possible for further evaluation to determine the cause and appropriate treatment. The physician will evaluate your symptoms, conduct necessary tests, and may prescribe appropriate medications.

Remember to continue checking the baby's movements and report any changes to your healthcare provider. Stay hydrated and take ample rest.
625:
Your symptoms could indicate a number of conditions and it's difficult to provide a diagnosis without doing any physical examination or tests. However, from what you've described, you may be experiencing an infection (e.g. throat infection) causing the neck gland pain and feverish symptoms. Night sweats may suggest that your body is trying to fight off the infection.  

The metallic taste could be a side effect of some medications if you're taking any, or it could be due to other reasons like poor oral health, sinus issues or even dehydration. The aches in your fingers and toes might be connected to circulatory issues or nerve problems, but it could also be due to other reasons, such as arthritis or vitamin deficiency. 

I strongly suggest you consult with a healthcare professional who can look into your symptoms more closely and perhaps order some tests to help reach a diagnosis. It's important not to ignore these symptoms, particularly as they have been ongoing for a year. Seeking medical assistance will allow you to get the any necessary treatment as soon as possible. Please remember to disclose all your medical history, medications and any lifestyle habits to the doctor.
626:

627: Hello, based on the information you provided, it sounds like your close friend may have a condition called a herniated disc in the cervical (neck) region of the spine. The cervical spine includes the C5, C6, C7, and C8 vertebrae. When a disc shifts or protrudes, it can press on spinal nerves, causing discomfort, and possibly neurological symptoms like numbness or weakness in limbs. The exact problem, though, should be diagnosed by a neurologist or a spine specialist, who can conduct a thorough examination and possibly order imaging tests. This consultation will provide an in-depth understanding of his condition and appropriate treatment options, which might include continued physiotherapy, medication, and in some cases, surgery. However, it's important to know that only a specialist can provide an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan. Hope this explanation helps. Let me know if I can assist you further.
628: I'm sorry to hear about your mother's discomfort. If the cefpodoxime is causing her nausea, it would be best to consult with her doctor about possibly switching medications. With her history of tolerating Novaclox well, it seems like a reasonable substitution, but her doctor should make the final decision as they are familiar with her medical history and the specifics of her current situation. 629:
Hi Greg, 
The MRI brain result you're referring to shows that there are changes in the white matter of both cerebral hemispheres that are consistent with chronic ischemia - a condition when there is insufficient blood flow to the brain over a long period of time. This can be caused by arteriosclerotic changes, a disease in which the arteries become hardened and narrow, leading to reduced blood flow. The small vessels (called capillaries) become less efficient at delivering blood to the brain tissue. 

These ischemic changes are often found in patients with high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol levels, or in smokers. This is generally a common age-related process, but can be accelerated by the afore-mentioned risk factors. 

The fact that there's no mass effect or midline shift means that there is no large mass (such as a tumor) pushing structures in the brain out of their normal position.
The rest of the brain such as basal ganglia, cerebellar hemispheres, brainstem, internal auditory canal, ventricular system, sellar and parasellar regions, and calvarium, are all normal.

In terms of management, if there are stroke-like symptoms or risk factors like those I've mentioned, these should be addressed to slow down the progression of the disease. This usually involves lifestyle changes and potentially medication. You should discuss these aspects with your mother's doctor, who will be able to provide appropriate advice taking into account other health factors.

I hope
630:
Hello, while it's understandable that you're concerned about the growing pain, it typically does take a little longer for antibiotics to start showing their effects. Amoxicillin usually starts working 24-72 hours after you start taking it, but the inflammation and pain may persist for several days. However, the relief from pain is not an indication of the infection resolving; you should complete the full course of the antibiotic provided by your dentist.

If your pain worsens or persists beyond 72 hours, or if you experience any new symptoms, you should contact your dentist immediately. The infection might require a different antibiotic, an increase in dosage, or a dental procedure like draining the abscess or a root canal treatment.

In the meantime, over-the-counter pain relievers and warm salt water rinses (half a teaspoon of salt in 8 ounces of warm water) may help alleviate your pain. Remember, do not stop taking the antibiotic prematurely and always follow your dentist's advice.

Please remember that my advice is intended to be used as a guide and it's always a good idea to seek the opinion and assistance of a healthcare professional who can review your individual circumstances.
631:
I'm really sorry to hear about your father's condition. It's tough to see a loved you one going through this. Your father's condition sounds serious, and I understand why you're worried. Sometimes individuals have personal reasons for not wanting to undergo further treatment. It may be fear, stress about costs, poor perceived quality of life post-surgery, or many other factors. 

It's crucial to have an open and honest discussion with him about his concerns and wishes, and to also involve his doctors in these conversations. It's also worth considering bringing a psychotherapist or counselor to help mediate these difficult talks.

Remember, this is ultimately his decision to make. All you can do is make sure that he's fully informed about his condition, what surgery would entail, and the possible risks and benefits.

It sounds like he might benefit from palliative care, which focuses on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of serious illnesses. It’s an approach that improves the quality of life for both the patient and the family. 

Lastly, don't forget to take care of yourself during this difficult time. It can be very stressful being involved in the care and decision-making process for a loved one who is ill.
632: Hello and thank you for your query. The symptoms you've described, particularly the tongue rolling back and speech issues, are not normal and could potentially indicate a serious health issue. It's important that your partner seek immediate medical attention, especially if these symptoms are recurring. These could potentially be signs of a neurological condition, including transient ischemic attack (TIA, also known as a "mini-stroke"), or could be related to alcohol withdrawal or excessive alcohol consumption. Smoking can also contribute to these health issues. Please make sure your partner consults with a healthcare professional urgently.
633:
Hello. It's difficult to make a definitive diagnosis without examining your son myself, but based on your description, it could be a number of things. This could be an ulceration, or it could be a harmless inflammatory reaction like an irritation fibroma or pyogenic granuloma, which can occur in response to a mild trauma like biting the cheek.

However, if this spot keeps coming back or does not fully go away in another 2 weeks, or if it changes in appearance or your son starts experiencing other symptoms, it may be worth seeking a second opinion just to be certain.

634:
Hello,
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling unwell. Your symptoms sound quite severe. While it could be a variant of migraine (such as hemiplegic migraine or occipital neuralgia), we can't rule out potentially significant causes such as cerebrovascular events given these are new symptoms. It's quite important that you receive a comprehensive neurologic examination and possibly undergo imaging like a CT or MRI scan. Please seek immediate medical attention, such as going to the emergency department, given the severity and acuteness of your symptoms.
635:
Hello, I understand your concern. If you've been trying for 6 months, don't worry as it can take a year for even healthy couples to conceive. Sticking to a regular sex schedule, especially during the woman's fertile window, can increase your chances. The fertile window usually spans 6 days – the day of ovulation and the 5 days preceding it. Having regular unprotected sex every 2 to 3 days throughout your menstrual cycle will give you the best chance of conceiving.

As for the supplements you mentioned - yes, they can assist with enhancing fertility, particularly folic acid as it is crucial for a baby's neural tube development and can reduce the risk of neural tube defects. Folic acid is usually recommended to be taken several months before you plan to conceive.

However, it is ideal to have a complete checkup with your doctor who can guide you thoroughly about your nutritional needs & other essential things to improve fertility. Emotional stress also plays a role in conception. Therefore, maintaining a balanced diet, active lifestyle and a stress-free environment can help. 

Remember, while conceiving can be a challenge for some couples, try to stay positive, and do not hesitate to seek help if you need. Your doctor may recommend further fertility testing if you have not achieved pregnancy after 1 year of trying. Take care!
636:
It's understandable that you're concerned, particularly due to the location and persistent nature of your pain. It's certainly possible that the screws from your surgery could be causing some irritation or discomfort, especially if there has been some shift in their position over the years. That said, it's difficult to say definitively without an examination or imaging.

The presence of a blood clot typically presents with symptoms such as warmth, redness, swelling, and pain, but these symptoms can also occur with inflammation or infection. Given the chronic nature of your symptoms, a blood clot seems less likely, but it can't be completely ruled out without a proper medical evaluation.

It would be wise to consult with your healthcare provider or an orthopedic specialist about your symptoms. They can provide a thorough evaluation and may suggest imaging studies, like an X-ray or ultrasound, to get a clearer picture of what's going on. I strongly recommend you to not delay this.

In the meantime, make sure you are not overusing the leg, elevate the leg when possible, apply cold packs intermittently, and you may use over-the-counter pain relievers if you need them.

Always remember, any kind of advice given online is not a substitute for medical advice. Please reach out to your healthcare provider as soon as possible. 

Get well soon!
637:
Hi there. Nutrilite Tri-Iron Folic is essentially a nutritional supplement that contains iron and folic acid. Iron is crucial for overall health and vitality, while folic acid is specifically important for women who are trying to conceive as it helps prevent certain birth defects.

Taking this supplement is unlikely to directly help you conceive (unless you're deficient in these nutrients), but it can aid in preparing your body for a healthy pregnancy. As for asthma, there are no known interactions or harmful effects between this supplement and asthma. However, always consult your primary healthcare provider before starting any new supplement regimen.

With regards to your difficulty in conceiving, given that you've been trying for 2 years, it would be advisable to consult with a fertility specialist who can evaluate you and your partner's reproductive health more thoroughly. The issue could be due to a variety of reasons and it's crucial to identify this for effective treatment planning. 

In any case, while trying to conceive, maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and a balanced diet, and ensure that your asthma is well-managed under the supervision of your physician.
638:
Hello, Metronidazole is an antibiotic that is used to treat a wide variety of infections. It works by stopping the growth of certain bacteria and parasites. However, it will only work if the infecting bacteria are sensitive to metronidazole. Some skin infections respond better to other types of antibiotics. 

The most effective way to get rid of a skin infection will always be to see a doctor, who can properly diagnose the type of infection and prescribe the correct antibiotic. However, I understand that you do not have insurance and this may not be possible for you. 

Metronidazole can cause side effects, such as nausea, dizziness, stomach upset, and a metallic taste in your mouth. Do not drink alcohol while taking metronidazole and for at least 3 days after stopping the medicine. 

While you are self-treating, monitor for signs of worsening infection such as increasing redness, swelling, pain, and drainage. If these occur, stop taking the metronidazole and seek medical attention promptly. 

Finally, remember to take the medication until it's completely finished-infections can return if you do not complete the full course of antibiotics.

Please note that while I have provided advice to the best of my ability, this advice is not a substitute for a professional medical opinion. My advice does not establish a doctor-patient relationship. Please consult a healthcare provider before you decide to take metronidazole or any other medication.
639:
Hello AAA,

The symptoms you describe can be side effects of discontinuing Depo-Provera, especially noting that the shot can affect your body's hormonal balance for up to a year after the last injection. That being said, it's also possible that these symptoms could be related to pregnancy. However, as you've mentioned, you've taken a home pregnancy test and it's negative. 

Depo-Provera should not cause a 'false negative' result on a home pregnancy test. If you still haven't gotten your period and continue to experience these symptoms, it would be a good idea to contact your healthcare provider. They may want to conduct a blood pregnancy test to rule out early pregnancy as a cause of your symptoms. It might be necessary to explore other causes too, such as hormonal imbalances or other conditions.

Remember, this advice is intended to be general in nature, and specific causes may not apply to your situation. Always consult with a healthcare provider for accurate information.
640:
Hello. From your description, it sounds like you are dealing not only with hemorrhoids but also possibly an anal abscess, or a small boil like you mentioned. It would be less likely to be a fistula if there is no discharge. However, since it is recurring and causing discomfort, I strongly recommend that you see a doctor to get it evaluated. If it is an abscess, it may need to be drained, and potentially may require antibiotics if there is an infection. 

In the meantime, you can continue the sitz baths and cold packs. Those are useful both for hemorrhoids and for perianal discomfort. Over-the-counter pain medications may be of some use as well. For your diet, try to consume foods rich in fiber and keep yourself hydrated to ensure you do not eliminate hard stool which can exacerbate the condition. A stool softener like docusate can also be very helpful. 

Again, please make an appointment with your primary care doctor or a specialist (such as a proctologist) in order to get this properly diagnosed and treated. Take care.
641:
Hello,

The normal sperm count is 20 million/ml or more, so your sperm count is on the lower side. In regards to motility, at least 50% of spermatozoa should have normal motility. Your motility is at 10%, which is quite low.

Though the presence of pus cells could indicate an infection which may have negatively impacted your sperm count and motility.

My advice would be as follows:

1. Consult a urologist to treat any possible infections as indicated by the presence of pus cells. You may need a course of antibiotics.

2. Abstain from smoking and alcohol, maintain a healthy diet rich in antioxidants (found in fruits and vegetables) and consider starting a regular exercise routine.

3. The parameters could improve naturally after the treatment of any infection. However, if there is no improvement, you may need further evaluation and a possible referral to a fertility specialist.

Please persist and stay positive, infertility is challenging but with modern medicine there are various treatments available. Best of luck to you.
642: Hi, what you're describing could be the normal production of pre-ejaculatory fluid or "pre-cum". This is something that your body does whenever it becomes aroused, such as during sexual thoughts, touching, or activities. It is completely normal and should not be something that you have to worry about. However, if you are experiencing pain, discomfort, or if the secretion is itchy, has a foul smell, or the color changes, it would be best to consult with a healthcare provider to rule out possibilities of an infection or other conditions. Nevertheless, it's important to maintain good hygiene to prevent any potential problems. Hope this helps.
643:
Hello, firstly I understand how frustrating and potentially distressing OCD can be. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is a common, treatable mental health issue that affects many people. Some people find that cognitive-behavioral therapy can be very effective in controlling and even eliminating their OCD symptoms.

Regarding your pronunciation problem, it's best to remind yourself that there may not be a universally 'correct' pronunciation for many names and brands, especially as pronunciation can differ between regions and accents. Therefore, there's no need to stress about it. 

Generally, to deal with OCD, you have to train your brain to tolerate the doubt, the fear, and the uncertainty. When the intrusive thoughts appear in your mind, acknowledge them without trying to refute them or act on them, and let them pass.

Please remember that while this advice may be useful, it's important to consult a mental health professional who can provide you with a personalized treatment plan for managing your OCD symptoms based on your specific needs.
644: Hello, it seems like you have concerns about a lump on your waist. It's great that you're scheduled to have an ultrasound, as it will provide more information about this lump you're feeling. Given its location and description, it could be a variety of things such as a lipoma (benign fat tissue tumor), a cyst, or even a hernia. The term "tissue band" may refer to a thickening of fascia (connective tissue under the skin), which can sometimes occur and create a lump-like feeling. It's difficult to confirm without imaging or physical examination. The ultrasound will help determine the nature of this lump and guide the next steps. Continue with the planned ultrasound as suggested by your doctor. Let's wait for the results and discuss further. Don't hesitate to ask if you have more questions.
645:
I'm sorry to hear that your daughter is going through this. It definitely does seem like your daughter's mental health needs to be prioritized. Experiencing prolonged periods of depression in conjunction with increased paranoia can potentially indicate an underlying psychiatric condition that is best addressed by a medical professional.

The steps you've mentioned are all great; indeed, it would be helpful for her to start counseling as well as getting a psychiatric assessment to explore whether antidepressant or other psychiatric medication might be beneficial. A thorough neurologic evaluation is also recommended to rule out any organic brain issues, especially given the recent history of falls.

Please note that it's vital to ensure that your daughter is actively participating and consenting to these treatments. Mental health care is incredibly personal and it's essential that your daughter feels comfortable and engaged with whoever she's working with.

In the meantime, provide a supportive and understanding environment that encourages open dialogue around mental health. Try to reassure her that her feelings are valid and it's okay to seek help. Maintaining a sense of routine, encouraging a healthy lifestyle and promoting activities she enjoys can also aid her recovery.
646:
Hello, I understand your concern. Emergency contraceptive pills, like i-pill, are most effective if taken within 24 hours and still provide protection if taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. The effectiveness of emergency contraception decreases with time after unprotected sex. However, considering you have taken the i-pill within 36 hours, it should have significantly reduced your chances of getting pregnant and was a responsible step to take.

The fact that you had unprotected sex two days after ovulation may lessen your chances of getting pregnant, as the egg is only viable for 12-24 hours after ovulation. Sperm, however, can live up to 5 days inside a woman's body. 

As for the withdrawal bleeding, it varies from woman to woman and does not necessarily occur on a schedule. The i-pill can make your periods irregular for the cycle it was used, by either delaying it or making it come early.

Even with emergency contraception, pregnancy is still a possibility. I would recommend waiting until your expected period date and if you miss this period, a pregnancy test could provide more clarity.

Remember, using emergency contraception regularly is not advisable and it's better to use a long term effective method. Always consult with a healthcare provider for the best contraceptive methods suitable for you. Taking HIV, STDs, and other factors into consideration is crucial. Practice safe sex to protect your health.
647:
Hi, Thanks for asking. Bone and prostate cancer are serious conditions and the treatments, such as radiation therapy, can sometimes affect the body's ability to produce blood cells, including platelets and hemoglobin. This may be what's causing your boyfriend's low levels. 

Transfusions are a common method to temporarily raise these levels. However, whether his platelet and hemoglobin levels will return to normal on their own depends on several factors, including the extent of the cancers, the effectiveness of his treatments, and his overall health. 

The most important thing is to ensure he is receiving appropriate treatment for his cancers and managing any side effects, such as the low platelet and hemoglobin levels. His doctor should be monitoring these levels closely and adjusting treatment as necessary. 

Please voice any concerns or questions to his healthcare team. They can provide the most accurate advice according to his specific medical situation. Always stay hopeful and positive, your support is vital for his recovery. I wish you both all the best.
648:
Low iron levels in a child of this age is a concern, especially if he appears pale and has low energy. Iron is crucial for the production of red blood cells and hemoglobin which carry oxygen throughout the body. Without it, your child may have problems with growth and development, as well as general fatigue and weakness.

An iron level of 8 is low for a child of his age, and failing response to oral iron (Ferritin) certainly needs further investigation. This could mean a malabsorption issue, an ongoing blood loss or less commonly, another medical issue.

I'd recommend seeking a second opinion and consider a referral to a pediatric hematologist (a specialist in blood disorders in children) for further assessment and management. Until then, continue to provide iron-rich foods such as meats, beans, fortified cereals, and green leafy vegetables. It's also beneficial to couple these with Vitamin C rich foods like oranges, as they improve iron absorption.

Delaying appropriate management could lead to iron deficiency anemia - a severe form of iron deficiency which has more serious implications like impaired cognitive and motor development.

Please take this situation seriously and seek further evaluation and management.

Your child's health is important and any concerns you have should be addressed.
649: I'm sorry to hear your daughter is experiencing this. Normally sternum pain by itself could be related to costochondritis which is inflammation in chest wall area, or muscle strain, heartburn indeed, or even more severe conditions like heart disease. However, the combination of symptoms you described including difficulty swallowing and difficulty breathing alongside the sternum pain sound concerning. It could point to a condition called esophagitis, aspiration pneumonia, or in rarer instances a mass in the chest. I recommend going to the ER, particularly if she is experiencing trouble breathing. It is important that she be seen as soon as possible to figure out what is going on and get appropriate intervention.
650: Hello, After getting fillings, some discomfort is normal because the filling process can irritate the nerve inside the tooth. It should subside within a week or two. Pain when eating, however, could indicate a problem. This might be because the filling is too high, as your second dentist suggested, or there might be an issue with the nerves inside your tooth. Now, filing down the filling was a good first step, but if the discomfort persists you should certainly get it checked out again. You may need to go for an X-ray to determine the nature of the problem. Meanwhile you may try a sensitivity toothpaste and avoid extreme temperature foods. Kindly make an appointment to see your dentist again if the problem persists.
651: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this pain. You must contact your Orthopedic specialist immediately for thorough examination and proper diagnostics; pain that's severe enough to disrupt sleep shouldn't be ignored. This could be a nerve-related issue, a problem with circulation, or an issue related to the previous surgery. In the interim, you should continue to keep the leg elevated and try using a hot or cold compress for temporary relief. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen may also help, but the severity and duration of your symptoms indicate that you need to be seen by a specialist as soon as possible.
652:
Hi, thank you for your question. Your semen volume is a bit unclear as the unit of measurement is missing, typically it's in milliliters (ml) and the normal range is around 1.5ml to 7ml. A sperm count of 7 million is low as in general, doctors like to see a count of at least 20 million sperm per ml of semen. Sperm motility is important as well, average or 'normal' motility is considered to be 40% or more. This means that healthy sperm are likely to move and 'swim' and a motility of 35% is a bit lower than preferred.

However, it's important to remember that these numbers are just general guidelines and many men with lower numbers are still able to father children naturally. If you're finding it difficult to conceive naturally, I would recommend seeing a healthcare provider for further investigation on both your and your partner's fertility. Treatments are often available to help with these issues. 

In the meantime, maintaining a healthy lifestyle can help improve semen quality. This includes regular exercise, a balanced diet, maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking, and keeping alcohol consumption to a minimum.
653:
I'm glad you reached out for advice. Pravastatin, like other statin medications, is known to potentially cause elevated liver enzymes in some people. It's a good idea to take a break from the medicine to see if your liver enzyme levels go back down to normal. A period of 4-6 weeks is generally sufficient to affect liver enzyme levels; however, it's always best to follow your doctor's advice. 

Typically if the liver enzymes decrease after stopping the medication, it suggests that the liver can recover, which is good news. It doesn't necessarily mean that pravastatin can be resumed without any risk, though—it simply indicates that the drug may have been causing the increase in the first place. 

After your follow-up tests, your doctor may consider adjusting your dosage or prescribing a different medication for your high cholesterol. That's because even if pravastatin was the cause of your elevated liver enzymes, other statins might be safer for your liver while still effectively lowering your cholesterol.

Remember, medications are only one approach to controlling cholesterol. Discuss with your doctor about lifestyle modifications such as changes to your diet, weight loss, and regular physical activity that can help you maintain healthy cholesterol levels.

Please follow up with your doctor as advised and don't hesitate to seek out other medical opinions if you're not satisfied with the responses you receive. Because everyone's situation is unique, it's critical to have a personalized plan of care. And remember to never change or
654: Hi, sorry to hear about your uncomfortable situation. Pulling a muscle, especially while pregnant, can be extremely painful. Complete rest is recommended for such cases, because overusing the muscle can cause further harm. Applying heat to the affected area can help to soothe and relax the muscle. Painful breathing and sneezing could suggest that the muscle pull was in the chest or rib area. You can take paracetamol safely during pregnancy for pain relief, but avoid taking ibuprofen as it's not safe for pregnant women in the third trimester. However, take your doctor's advice before starting any medication. I also strongly recommend seeing a physical therapist to properly evaluate your stance and the way you're using the crutches to ensure that you're not overusing or straining other muscles. If the pain is not improving or worsening over time, I recommend you go to the ER immediately to rule out any other more serious injuries, such as a rib fracture. Hope you feel better soon.
655:
Hello Ashton, first off, self-medication (including taking someone else's prescriptions) can be dangerous and is not recommended. It's good to see that you're reaching out for assistance, though. Based on your description, it does seem like you could be struggling with ADHD or ADD, particularly since there is a family history of the same. Symptoms like a wandering mind, difficulty in maintaining a schedule, inability to keep focus, and impulsive spending are common indicators. However, a professional diagnosis is crucial. 

Please, reach out to a healthcare professional in your area to discuss these concerns. They can do a proper evaluation and suggest the right treatment options. There are several effective treatments for ADHD, including medication, psychotherapy, education or training, or a combination of treatments. 

Remember, it may take some time to find what works best for you. It's a process and can be frustrating, but it's important to be patient and keep in close contact with your doctor. Discuss any concerns you have about medications with them. It's the best way to ensure you find the right treatment for your ADHD.
656:
I'm really sorry to hear about your mom's current health situation. Both Remeron (Mirtazapine) and Risperidone are commonly used in the treatment of depression and other psychiatric disorders. From a psychiatric perspective, these medications are generally considered safe when administered under the supervision of a healthcare professional. However, all medications carry some risk of side effects. 

In general, Risperidone is an antipsychotic medication used to treat symptoms of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and irritability associated with autistic disorder. Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that is also used to treat anxiety, and sometimes prescribed for patients with dementia who have depression or behavioral issues. 

It's very important that the doctor prescribing these medications is well aware of her full medical history including her bypass surgery in 1997 and her heart attacks. These medications should be used very cautiously in the elderly, especially those with existing heart disease, since they can sometimes lead to changes in heart rhythm or blood pressure. It’s also important to carefully monitor her for any new or worsening symptoms. 

Please be sure to express your concerns to the healthcare team. Frequent communication will help to ensure that they have all the information that they need to care for your mom in the best possible way.
657: I am sorry to hear about your wife's diagnosis. However, it is encouraging that there are no signs of distant metastasis according to the PET scan. The involvement of the lymph nodes suggests a high risk of cancer recurrence, thus the recommendation for chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The plan proposed by your oncologist is standard for such a case. The aim of chemotherapy is to kill any cancer cells that may have spread from the breast to other parts of the body, but are too small to be seen on the scans. Radiation therapy aims to kill any remaining cancer cells in and around the breast or armpit. This is often used after surgery to reduce the risk of the cancer returning in the same breast. I know chemotherapy might sound scary, but modern drugs and supportive care are more effective in managing side effects compared to years ago. Finally, remember that it's incredibly important to have open discussions with your oncology team about your concerns and the pros and cons of therapy.
658: Hello, there are rare reports of kidney issues associated with the ChatDoctor injections. However, this discomfort could be due to various reasons such as kidney stones, urinary tract infections, or even unrelated issues like muscle strain. It's important not to assume and get a proper diagnosis. I would recommend seeing your healthcare provider promptly. They might want to conduct some tests, such as a urine analysis or a renal function test, to ascertain the cause of your discomfort. Then, appropriate treatment can be started. Please keep monitoring your symptoms and seek immediate medical attention if they worsen.
659:
Hello, It's certainly challenging to see your little one go through this. As a doctor, I would highly recommend continuing with the hearing aid as that's the most scientifically validated method of treating Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SHL).

Regarding her blocked nose and frequent colds, it sounds like she may be suffering from a type of allergy, possibly allergic rhinitis. This making it important that you manage and reduce her exposure to potential allergens, such as dust mites or pet dander.

She should also be evaluated by a pediatric allergist or an ENT specialist. Medications such as antihistamines, decongestants, and nasal steroids could be used depending on the severity and frequency of symptoms. In some cases, allergy immunotherapy (allergy shots) could be recommended by the allergist.

Regarding homeopathic treatment, while some individuals find improvement in their symptoms, the efficacy of homeopathic treatments is often individual and it has not been proven consistently in large, controlled clinical trials. It's important to discuss these options with a healthcare provider who is familiar with your daughter's medical history.

Remember that managing symptoms will provide the most relief. Maintain good hydration, use saline nasal sprays to keep nasal passages moist, and consider using a humidifier in her room while she sleeps. 

It's important that she sees a pediatrician or an ENT specialist to address these issues further. These tips can help alleviate her symptoms in the meantime. 

Thank you, and take care.
660:
I'm very sorry to hear about the loss of your mom and the current condition of your sister. I understand your concerns and your feelings of responsibility.

The episode you described with your mom sounds like what is often described as a "terminal event" or "agonal event." These can be very distressing to witness, but they're typically due to the brain's reaction to lowered oxygen and blood flow, not due to too much oxygen being given. It's unlikely that oxygen administration contributes to these types of events. Oxygen is often used in end-of-life care to make patients more comfortable.

The use of oxygen in patients with advanced cancer who are nearing the end of life is generally safe provided it's appropriately administered and monitored. Typically, oxygen use can help relieve symptoms of breathlessness and hypoxia in these patients.

Always remember that as a healthcare proxy, your role was to carry out your mom's healthcare wishes to the best of your ability, and based on the information you had. If you have questions or concerns, I would encourage you to speak with your sister's doctor. They can provide clarification and reassurance about these matters.
661:
Based on the symptoms you've described, it does sound like you could have internal hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus that can be itchy, painful, and potentially cause bleeding during bowel movements. Internal hemorrhoids can become prolapsed, meaning they protrude from the anus, but they also tend to retract on their own after bowel movements or when relaxing/standing. They can often result from straining during bowel movements or sitting for extended periods of time on the toilet. 

However, it's important not to self-diagnose. I would strongly suggest that you see a doctor or specialist such as a gastroenterologist or proctologist for proper evaluation and treatment. Remember, there's no need to be embarrassed - they are medical professionals trained to deal with such issues. 

For temporary relief, over-the-counter remedies like hemorrhoid creams or suppositories can be used. Increasing fiber in your diet can also help by softening your stool and making it easier to pass. Warm sitz baths might provide some relief as well. 

If you notice an increase in bleeding, pain, or if the lump does not retreat, please seek medical care urgently.
662: Certainly it is a concern because the symptoms seem to be worsening and not getting better. The back pain could be due to body aches related to the fever. The fever and body aches seem consistent with a flu or a flu-like illness. Even though you are otherwise healthy and young, flu can make you much sicker than a common cold. Given your exposure to Streptococcal infection and recent worsening of symptoms, it would be wise to revisit your doctor to get rechecked. Streptococcal infections, if left untreated may lead to more serious conditions. Try to rest, keep yourself hydrated. Try to keep pain and fever down with over-the-counter medications like Tylenol or Ibuprofen.
663:
Hello, often a traumatic injury like this can cause damage not only to the skin, but also to the underlying tissues, including the muscles and connective tissues. Although the wound on the skin may have healed, the tissues beneath might still be in a process of repair. 

However, the redness and swelling around the wound can also be signs of inflammation or infection. Without warmth, it's less likely to be an infection, but it's still a possibility. You should seek medical attention if you're experiencing increasing pain, the swelling is expanding, or you develop systematic symptoms like fever. 

In this case, your best option is to see a healthcare provider for further evaluation to ensure there is no infection or other complication occurring that would require treatment. If you're not experiencing any limitations in your mobility and no worsening symptoms, it might still be part of the healing process. So don't worry too much. Please keep monitoring the area closely and seek medical attention as needed.
664:
I'm sorry to hear about your extended discomfort. Given the circumstances and the fact that the pain has persisted for weeks following trauma, I'd recommend seeking another medical opinion. An orthopedist or a sports medicine specialist may be more equipped to identify any potential musculoskeletal injuries from your football incidences. Imaging like X-rays or an MRI scan can also help in identifying any structural issues - disc problems, fractures, or other soft tissue injuries that might not be immediately noticeable. In the meantime, avoid strenuous physical activities that might increase the pain.
Please remember that while over-the-counter pain medication may offer temporary relief, they are not a long-term solution and overuse can lead to other health problems. Applying ice or heat to the painful areas might also provide temporary relief.
665:
Hello, You are obviously concerned about your son. If your child isn't eating but is drinking plenty of fluids, that's a good sign as it means he's not dehydrating. The fever is also not abnormally high for a child. Small children often get fevers when fighting off infections or illnesses, so it isn't necessarily a cause for alarm unless it won't go down after several days, or if it gets any higher. 

However, if the fever lasts longer than 5 days, it's necessary to see a medical professional, since it could be something more serious. It can also be a hint that the body is having a hard time fighting off the illness. 

These illnesses can be bacterial, in which case antibiotics might be needed. But more often than not, they are viral illnesses such as the flu or a cold. 

So in summary, keep doing what you're doing but if after 5 days your son's condition doesn't improve, consult with a healthcare provider again. If his demeanor changes drastically, he has difficulty breathing, has a rash or is unable to keep down fluids, seek immediate medical attention. 

You should always follow your instincts as a parent; you know your son better than anyone.
666: Hello, I understand your concerns given your previous history of breast cancer. It's important to clarify that both scar tissue and cancerous lumps can bleed during a biopsy and the presence or absence of bleeding or bruising afterward doesn't necessarily indicate one or the other. The biopsy needle often goes through blood vessels, which can cause bleeding and subsequently bruising, but this can vary widely from person to person based on their individual biology, including their platelet count, clotting factors, and the specific site of the biopsy. Also, there is variation in the way our bodies react to trauma and some people might develop bruising and others might not. So, I'd suggest waiting for the biopsy results for a definitive answer. In case of persistent worry or new symptoms, contact your healthcare provider promptly.
668:
Hello,

Intracranial aneurysms can be a cause of concern, but it's encouraging that your neurologist believes it's something you may have had for a long time. Your age, the size of the aneurysm, and its location are all things that must be considered when deciding a course of treatment. 

Given the small size of your aneurysm (4mm), it's not entirely surprising that your neurologist chose to monitor rather than perform a coiling procedure immediately. This is often the approach taken for small aneurysms, especially when there's a risk to vision like in your case.

Aneurysms can remain stable, stay the same size, or grow slowly over time. There is also a small risk of rupture, which is why your neurologist will continue to monitor its size and position.

The best thing you can do is to control your risk factors for growth or rupture, which include high blood pressure, smoking, alcohol intake, and high cholesterol. Staying active, following a balanced diet, and regular checkups with your neurologist are other important steps towards maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

Remember, it's normal to be concerned after a diagnosis like this. It's good that you're questioning and learning. I would recommend discussing any further concerns with your neurologist the next time you see them. They can provide more personalized advice and reassurances.
669:
Thank you for your question. From your description, it might be a muscle strain or a sprain from poor sleeping posture or heavy lifting. You may however also be experiencing kidney problems, so it's important to note any other symptoms you might have such as fever, burning or pain during urination, frequent urination and changes in the color of your urine. 

Some home remedies include resting and avoiding strenuous activities for a few days, applying a warm or cold compress to the affected area and over-the-counter pain relievers. 

I would advise you to book an appointment with your primary care doctor as soon as possible to get a proper diagnosis. If the pain is severe and persistent, or is accompanied by other signs and symptoms like fever, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements, seek immediate medical help. It's always better to be safe and get a professional opinion, especially when it comes to abdominal and lower back pain.
670:
I'm sorry to hear about your father's health issue. However, persistent symptoms like these, that both a cardiologist and gastroenterologist cannot attribute to their fields of specialization, may warrant a more comprehensive approach. The symptoms you mention could arguably be due to nerve impingements or other musculoskeletal origins. Additionally, these symptoms can be associated with anxiety or other psychological issues, which can be common following major surgery. 

A neurologist or a pain specialist may be able to give further insights or recommendation for managing these symptoms, ruling out conditions such as neuropathy. A psychiatric evaluation could also be helpful if anxiety is contributing to these problems. Furthermore, a second opinion from another cardiologist or gastroenterologist may be worth considering. In any case, pursuing this with healthcare professionals until you get satisfactory answers is advised. 

Remember that it is also crucial to ensure that your father is compliant with all his post-operation medication, and make certain he reports any changes he experiences.
671:
I'm sorry to hear that your granddaughter is not feeling well. Her symptoms suggest she could be dealing with a stomach bug (gastroenteritis), which is common in young children and usually runs its course within a week or two. Stomach bugs can causes vomiting and the inability to keep food down, as well as make a child seem weak and irritable. Ensuring she's hydrated is critical, especially if vomiting is persistent. Small sips of rehydration solutions (like Pedialyte) throughout the day can help.

Her paleness could be due to the sickness itself or it may suggest that she's not getting enough iron in her diet, which can cause anemia. 674:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is primarily a blood-borne virus, and the most common modes of infection are through exposure to small quantities of blood such as from sharing needles, syringes or other injecting drug equipment, from the mother to the baby at the time of birth, and through sexual contact.

In your case, if your mother's blood came into contact with your son's skin or mouth, the risk of transmission exists, but it is incredibly low, especially if there are no open wounds, cuts, or sores in the mouth or on the skin that could have come into contact with the virus.

I understand that you are worried and it's important to remember that hepatitis C virus is not transmitted through casual or brief contact, like hugging, kissing, sneezing, coughing, or even food sharing, unless the blood of the infected person has a route to the bloodstream of another person.

You should get tested as a precaution since you were born to a mother with Hep C, though the risk of transmission during childbirth is low. As for your son, you can always seek advice from your healthcare provider but given your description, the risk seems extremely low. 

Always remember, there's no single piece of advice that will fit all situations and individuals differ. When in doubt, it's always better to consult with your healthcare provider.
675:

Before going for surgery, there are several other non-surgical treatment options that can be tried like:

1. Physical Therapy: A physical therapist can teach exercises designed to improve flexibility and strength, which ultimately delivers more supportive lower back and leg muscles.

2. Pain medication: Non-prescription medications may be enough to help. If not, stronger prescription drugs can be used which includes muscle relaxants or in some cases narcotic painkillers.

3. Steroid Injections: If the pain is severe, injecting steroids into the area around the spinal nerves might suppress inflammation and relieve the pain.

Surgery is usually the last resort if all other treatments fail and if the pain is severe and disabling after ample period of conservative treatments. Following a correct course of treatment usually brings relief in couple of months. You may consult a neurologist or a neurosurgeon to discuss and explore these options.

680:

687:

688:
In the case of head injuries, it's important to watch for signs of a more serious injury. These would include loss of consciousness after the impact, excessive sleepiness, repeated vomiting, unsteady walk, seizures, severe headache, confusion, unusual behavior or personality changes. Also, any changes in his vision or pupils not reacting the same way to light can indicate serious injuries.

If he is alert, oriented, doesn't have any of the above symptoms, and is able to walk and talk normally, the injury could possibly be minor. However, the swelling at the site of injury (goose egg) is quite normal after such injuries and should begin to resolve after a couple of days. The cold packs along with the paracetamol you've given him should help with pain and swelling.

If you're really worried, if he develops any of the above-mentioned symptoms, or if the swelling doesn't start to go down after a couple of days, then you should take him to the A&E just to be safe. If he seems alright otherwise, just make sure you continue to carefully observe him over the next 24-48 hours. It's generally better to be safe when it comes to head injuries, so if you are unsure, it is worth a trip to the ER.
689: I'm glad to hear you're feeling better. Anemia, or a low red blood cell count, can have many different causes. In order to fully understand why this happened to you, your doctor would need to conduct some further tests.
