Endometriosis can make it more difficult for you to become pregnant, but it's not impossible. Endometriosis may block the tube and keep the egg and sperm from uniting. But if the egg does meet up with a healthy sperm, endometriosis can keep the fertilized egg from implanting and growing normally in the uterus. 

However, you mentioned the rupture of follicles in the other ovary is healthy, which means that you could potentially conceive.

Regarding treatment, it usually depends on the extent of your endometriosis, your symptoms, and whether you would like to become pregnant. Medications can help to slow the progression of endometriosis and alleviate the symptoms, but won't help you conceive.

Surgery is the most effective treatment method and would be recommended if you're not getting pregnant because of endometriosis. Laparoscopic or keyhole surgery can be used to remove or destroy the areas of endometriosis in your body, thereby increasing your chances of pregnancy.

As for your diet, there is no specific list of foods that should be avoided strictly when you are planning for a pregnancy. However, maintaining a healthy diet will improve your health overall and can improve your chances of conception. There is also some evidence that eating a diet high in fruits, vegetables, and lean protein can help improve fertility.

Hello and thank you for reaching out. If you were diagnosed with TB of the right apex and are taking your medications (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Rimactazid) regularly as prescribed by your doctor, the chance of being contagious significantly reduces, usually after a few weeks of continuous treatment. Your symptoms of cough and cold may not necessarily mean that you are infectious. 

However, to be on the safe side, here are some important dos and don'ts:

1) Do continue to take your medication exactly as prescribed and for the full duration even if you feel better. TB treatment takes a long time (usually around 6 months).
  
2) Do not skip doses or stop medication on your own. This can potentially make your TB more difficult to treat and cause drug resistance.
   
3) Do cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough, sneeze or laugh to prevent spreading germs. Dispose of the used tissue promptly and properly.
   
4) Don't spend a lot of time in closed-in spaces with other people. Try to avoid crowded places.

5) Ensure you are maintaining a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet, adequate sleep and moderate exercise. This can help boost your immune system and help your body fight the bacteria.

Talk to your healthcare provider about your new symptoms (especially the cough), they may want to re-test to ensure your treatment is working as it should be, or there may be something else causing your cough and cold

Hello Swastik, I'm sorry to hear about your discomfort. This type of prickly sensation is likely due to a condition known as cholinergic urticaria, a type of hives caused by changes in body temperature. 

In management of this condition, the primary aim is to reduce symptoms. Staying in cooler environments and avoiding activities that can raise your body temperature may help. 

Your medication, Prednisolone, helps in decreasing the body's immune response to allergens, hence reducing the symptoms. Septilin enhances immunity and offers resistance against common allergens. However, long term use of corticosteroids can have side effects and your body can also become less responsive over time, as you're experiencing. 

You may want to ask your doctor about alternatives such as antihistamines (like cetirizine, fexofenadine), leukotriene modifiers, or omalizumab (used in severe cases). Scratching or physical irritants can make your symptoms worse, so try to avoid this as well. 

Keeping a diary of your activities, foods and beverages you consume may help you identify specific triggers that worsen your symptoms. 

This is a chronic condition but it can be managed efficiently with definite trigger avoidance and appropriate medications. You should discuss these alternatives with your local healthcare provider. Please remember online advice is intended to supplement, not replace a full medical evaluation. Hope you find relief soon!

Hello, thanks for reaching out. Semen typically liquefies, or turns from a gel-like substance into a more water-like substance, within 20 to 30 minutes of ejaculation. If the semen does not liquefy within this time frame, it may suggest an issue with the seminal vesicles or the prostate, which are responsible for secreting the proteins required for liquefaction.

Long-standing diabetes can potentially impact the prostate's health and thus affect the liquefaction time. However, there may be other causes as well, such as infection or other prostate or seminal vesicle issues.

A delayed liquefaction time can possibly affect fertility, as it may hinder sperm motility, meaning it's harder for the sperm to move and reach an egg for fertilization.

I would suggest consulting with your doctor. They may wish to order further investigations to determine the cause of your prolonged liquefaction time. If an infection is indeed found to be the cause, antibiotics could be used to treat it. If prostate issues are discovered, medications could be used to help improve prostate health.

While this can be a concern, it doesn't necessarily equate to infertility. There are treatments and strategies that can be used to assist with conception, even if semen liquefaction is an issue. 

Remember, every patient is unique so be sure to consult with your healthcare provider for the best course of action.

Hello. Following surgical removal of wisdom teeth, it is common to experience some numbness or unusual sensations in the lower lip and chin for a while. This is due to the close anatomical relationship of the roots of the lower wisdom teeth with the Inferior alveolar nerve, an important sensory nerve in the jaw. The weird sensations can make you become more aware of the normal anatomy of your lip, such as salivary glands, fat or minor blood vessels which you interpret as 'vein like things'. 

However, if your symptoms worsen or persist after surgery, it's possible that you may have incurred some nerve damage during the procedure. This might be due to inflammation or bruising, or in relatively rare cases, the nerve might have been accidentally severed. However, with time these nerves usually regenerate and sensation gradually returns to normal.

The lump you are seeing is likely a dental abscess which can occur as a result of a long-standing dental caries or cavity. It appears that the infection from the tooth has spread to the gums. If left untreated, it can affect the developing permanent tooth and may spread to other areas leading to serious complications.

The recommended treatment options generally depend on the extent of the tooth decay and the condition of the tooth. If the decay is too severe or has affected the tooth's pulp, extraction might be the most effective treatment to fully address the infection and protect your child's oral health. It is important to remember that your child's baby teeth work as space savers for the permanent adult teeth, and losing one prematurely could lead to space loss and crowding of the permanent teeth.

However, in certain cases where the tooth is largely intact, a procedure known as pulpotomy (partial root canal therapy) can be considered to try and save the child's tooth.

Ultimately, the decision depends on many factors including the child's age, extent of decay, cooperation level during procedures, and more. It would be advisable to get a second opinion if you are uncertain about the extraction.

If you decide to proceed with the extraction, the dentist might consider a space maintainer to save the space for the unerupted permanent tooth.

This advice is based on general dental principles. You should discuss these options with your dentist before reaching to a final decision.

If you're experiencing pain in your chest every time you eat or drink, it could be because of a condition called gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). GERD occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus and cause the kind of discomfort you're experiencing. 

Another potential cause is esophageal spasm, a disorder of the esophagus that can cause symptoms such as chest pain and difficulty swallowing food and fluids. 

In rare cases, such symptoms might also be caused by serious conditions such as heart disease, even if the pain is triggered by swallowing.

Given your symptoms, I strongly advise you seek a medical evaluation as soon as possible. You should see a gastroenterologist to perform tests like an endoscopy. If your pain is severe, seek urgent care. It's always better to err on the side of caution where chest pain is concerned.

However, only a healthcare provider can provide a definitive diagnosis and it's best to seek medical consultation as soon as possible.
